how-often-clean-pool-florida.author: Kevin
how-often-clean-pool-florida.intro: One of the most common questions we get from new Florida homeowners is: "How often do I really need to clean my pool?" In many parts of the country, you might get away with bi-weekly service, but Florida is different.
content:
The Florida Factor: Heat and Humidity

Florida's subtropical climate creates the perfect breeding ground for algae and bacteria. The combination of intense sunlight, high heat, and regular rainfall means your pool requires more frequent attention than pools in cooler climates.

Weekly Service is the Standard

For 99% of Florida residential pools, weekly cleaning is the bare minimum to maintain sanitary and safe swimming conditions. During a weekly visit, a professional will:

  • Test and balance chemicals (pH, chlorine, alkalinity, stabilizer)
  • Skim the surface for debris
  • Brush the walls and tile line
  • Empty skimmer and pump baskets
  • Check the filter pressure
  • Vacuum as needed

When You Might Need More

There are times when even weekly service isn't enough. If you have heavy screened enclosure debris, a lot of swimmers (like during summer break), or after a heavy storm, you might need to check your baskets and skimmer in between professional visits.

The Impact of Rain

Florida's afternoon thunderstorms can dilute your pool's chemicals and introduce phosphates and other contaminants. Consistent weekly service ensures that your water chemistry is corrected before algae has a chance to take hold.
how-often-clean-pool-florida.conclusion: In summary, stick to a weekly schedule for the best results. Consistency is key to preventing expensive cleanup jobs down the road.

balance-pool-chemicals-hot-weather.author: Kevin
balance-pool-chemicals-hot-weather.intro: Balancing pool chemicals is a science, and Florida's scorching summer heat adds a variable that can throw everything off. As temperatures rise, chlorine dissipates faster, and pH levels can fluctuate wildly.
content:
Understanding Chlorine Demand

UV rays from the sun destroy chlorine. In the peak of prolonged Florida summer days, you might lose a significant amount of your free chlorine in just a few hours if your pool isn't properly stabilized. This is why Cyanuric Acid (Stabilizer) is your best friend—it acts like sunscreen for your chlorine.

Managing pH Levels

Higher temperatures can lead to scale formation if your pH and alkalinity aren't in check. We recommend keeping your pH slightly lower (around 7.4) during the hotter months to prevent scaling and eye irritation.

Shocking Your Pool

During heatwaves, regular chlorination might not be enough to handle the bather load and organic contaminants. A weekly or bi-weekly shock (super-chlorination) helps oxidize organic matter and keeps the water sparkling.

Don't Forget Circulation

Chemicals can't do their job if the water isn't moving. Ensure your pump is running long enough each day—typically 8-10 hours in the summer—to turn over the entire volume of water and distribute chemicals evenly.
balance-pool-chemicals-hot-weather.conclusion: Keeping your pool balanced in the heat requires vigilance. heavy bather loads and rainstorms make it even harder. If you're struggling to keep up, give us a call.

pool-pump-repair-signs.author: Kevin
pool-pump-repair-signs.intro: Your pool pump is the heart of your swimming pool system. It circulates water, ensuring chemicals are mixed and debris is filtered out. Like any mechanical device, it wears down over time. Catching issues early can save you from a complete and expensive replacement.
content:
1. Screeching or Grinding Noises

If your pump sounds like it has rocks inside or is screeching, the bearings are likely shot. This is often caused by age or a seal leak that let water into the motor. It needs immediate attention.

2. Hummming But Not Starting

If the motor hums but doesn't turn over, it could be a bad capacitor (a relatively cheap fix) or the motor itself could be seized. Don't leave it humming; it can overheat and burn out completely.

3. Leaking Water

Water pooling under the pump usually indicates a failed shaft seal. This is a common maintenance item that should be addressed to prevent water damage to the motor.

4. Sucking Air

If you see bubbles in the pump basket or return jets, there's a suction side air leak. This makes the pump work harder and reduces filtration efficiency. Check your pump lid o-ring first—it's the most common culprit.
pool-pump-repair-signs.conclusion: Listen to your equipment. If it sounds different, it probably needs help. Prompt repairs extend the life of your pool pump significantly.

salt-pool-vs-chlorine.author: Kevin
salt-pool-vs-chlorine.intro: Thinking of switching to salt? It's one of the most popular upgrades we see in Vero Beach. But is it right for you? Let's break down the differences between traditional chlorine pools and salt systems.
content:
It's Still a Chlorine Pool

First, a myth-buster: Salt pools ARE chlorine pools. A salt cell generator uses electricity to turn dissolved salt into pure chlorine. The difference is the delivery method and the quality of the water.

The Feel Factor

Salt water feels softer on the skin and is less irritating to eyes. It doesn't have the harsh chemical smell associated with traditional liquid or tablet chlorine pools. This is the #1 reason people switch.

Cost Comparison

Upfront: Salt systems cost more to install ($1,500 - $2,500+).
Ongoing: Salt is cheap. You'll stop buying buckets of chlorine tabs. Element cells last 3-7 years and cost $500-$900 to replace.

Maintenance

Salt pools are generally lower maintenance day-to-day, but they require specific attention to pH levels, which tend to drift up. You also need to clean the salt cell periodically to remove calcium buildup.
salt-pool-vs-chlorine.conclusion: If you want a more luxurious swim experience and simplified routine maintenance, salt is a great investment. If you're on a strict budget, traditional chlorine works just fine.

prevent-algae-florida-pool.author: Kevin
prevent-algae-florida-pool.intro: Algae is the uninvited guest that never wants to leave. In Florida, preventing algae is a year-round battle. Prevention is far cheaper and easier than the cure.
content:
1. Maintain Consistent Chlorine Levels

The moment your chlorine drops to near zero, algae spores can bloom. This often happens after heavy rains or heavy pool usage. check your levels at least weekly.

2. Brush, Brush, Brush

Algae loves to cling to porous surfaces like plaster. energetic brushing once a week disrupts the algae's protective slime layer and lets the chlorine do its work. Don't skip the walls and corners!

3. Circulation and Filtration

Dead spots with poor circulation are algae breeding grounds. Ensure your jets are pointed to create a circular flow. Clean your filter regularly so it can effectively trap spores.

4. Use Algaecide as Insurance

A weekly maintenance dose of a quality algaecide acts as a backup safety net. It helps prevent blooms even if your chlorine levels dip temporarily.
prevent-algae-florida-pool.conclusion: Process and routine are your best defense. A clean, well-circulated, and chemically balanced pool is an inhospitable environment for algae.

pool-turned-green.author: Kevin
pool-turned-green.intro: It happens to the best of us. You go away for a week, or the pump timer breaks, and suddenly your backyard oasis looks like a swamp. Don't panic—it can be fixed.
content:
Step 1: check Your Equipment

Before adding chemicals, make sure your pump and filter are working. You'll need to run them 24/7 during the cleanup process. Backwash or clean the filter immediately if flow is poor.

Step 2: Balance pH and Alkalinity

Chlorine is much more effective at a lower pH. Adjust your pH to 7.2-7.4 before shocking. This "supercharges" the shock treatment.

Step 3: Shock and Brush

Hit the pool with a heavy dose of liquid chlorine (shock). Brush the entire pool vigorously to scrub the algae off the walls and into the water where the chlorine can kill it.

Step 4: Filter and Clean

Run the filter continuously. You will likely need to clean the filter cartridges or backwash daily (or even multiple times a day) as the algae dies and clogs the system. If the water is cloudy grey/blue, the algae is dead; now it's a filtration game.
pool-turned-green.conclusion: Turning a green pool around takes patience and a lot of chemicals. If you can't see the bottom drain, it might be safer and faster to call a pro for a 'Green-to-Clean' service.
